												Gun is the great western game from the PS2-era, namely, 2005 year. Oh, sure, it is dated! But last time I checked, Rockstar still keeping its Red Dead Redemption to consoles, so there is still none a better open-world cowboy game on the PC.One thing Gun did good, the shootouts, were bested by the Juarez game series. But if you want an open world where you not only shooting deadbeats, but also shepherd cows, hunting buffalos, and, yeah, running mail quests, while riding your mustang… you still got only the Gun option.And it is a good option. Not only it is playable from the box, unlike many other 10 years old games, which Steam is releasing… The Gun is a very worthy still – in all aspects but visuals.“Open world” in this game, of course, can’t be compared to the newer games, like Fallout New Vegas. It is a vast territory somewhere diluted inhabited oases. You riding between them, reasonably expecting an ambush on every turn, behind every bush. By the way, horses are your best friends: you really don’t want to walk all the wilderness back to town. So don’t shoot them, and don’t allow others do so. Speaking of shooting, gunplay there is rather primitive, as you can expect from a console game, but at the same time, it allows you to enjoy a decent arsenal of the time, and unleash all the knots of the plot and game logic. So it is okay.About game plot. Although of course it is made full of cliches, in the endline, it is a good scenario. Not sure I want to read a book about, but, as a part of game, being sounded by good actors, it feels natural.As I said earlier, besides main quests and that dabbling revenge pursuing, you have many other opportunities to feel at home with Wild West around you. Visit cathouse, drink whiskey, play some poker, do some ranching, mining and hunting… both on animals and on wanted criminals. And of course, you can be a Sheriff in one place, and rob some trains in another.So, if you want a western game on the PC, try the Gun. At least now, despite the fact it is 10 years old title. Play it now, while it is still available and working, and there are no new game from the Rockstar or Techland, or some other studio with taste in the good old days of 19th century.While many fine games took some beef from the westerns, from Fallout New Vegas and even Mass Effect to japanese Wild Guns series… If we are talking about vanilla Wild West, not some Weird West, like in the Dark Watch or Damnation, we have so few decent games, that missing the Gun is almost a crime.Mark 8.1/10

			Views: 833		

			Gun is underrated and forgotten game. It's worth checking out Widscreen fix: http://thirteenag.github.io/widescreen_fixes_pack#gun http://store.steampowered.com/app/2610/ Follow me on Twitter:...		

For me this is one of my favorite games of all time and the best game set in the wild west. I know there are other, like Call of Juarez, but Gun, which is older, have far more interesting characters, world, story and I can safely say it's higher quality product, as far as the first Juarez. While the consoles have Red Dead Redemption, which by the looks of it is superior, PC have Gun, which is rough around the edges. I read somewhere, before RDR, Gun was the best western game. It may be rough, but this doesn't mean it's not fun. Unfortunately, it's far from perfect. It does have some problems, that might put off some people. It all depends of your tolerance for something far from perfect. Let me continue with bad stuff, so I can end on a positive note.This is a console port and it's obvious. It's not the worst, but this could be unacceptable for some. The game runs at 30 fps, which is not such big deal, I can close my eyes, but in some situation dips below that. It's an open world game, but it feels like it's divide by sectors and when you reach the border of some sector, the game need to load the surroundings and fps drops below 30. It's for e second, but it's annoying. There are some weird bugs. Few examples: NPC is giving me task and you can see his neck,arms and legs are not attached to the torso. In one side quest you can see in the distance, the enemies are riding … the air, or the legs of a horse are not moving. These bugs are more funny, than game breaking. The graphics didn't aged very well. For the time they were decent.Maybe the biggest problem is the presence of slight auto aim. Why is this in a PC game? It would be nice if I could turn it off. The answer is simple – console port. The developer of the game is Neversoft, which were famous with the Tony Hawk franchise, but for the port is responsible Beenox (known for the Spider-man games) and they didn't do good job. Here is the contradiction. Maybe the auto aim it's not a bad thing, since aiming with the mouse is not perfect, it's not that precise. I always compare 3rd person action games with Max Payne in this regard, because the aiming there is perfect for me and Gun is almost there. There are other 2 small problems. The first is the AI – sometimes it's just stupid and second one is the enemy models. You will see the same characters over and over.After all I said, maybe you are asking yourself is there any good things in the game? Yes, there is. Absolutely love the game. Almost 10 years later, you can see the higher quality of the game, starting with the voice acting. The main characters are voiced by famous hollywood actors, like Thomas Jane, Kriss Kristoffersen, Lance Henriksen, Brad Dourif, Ron Perlman, Tom Skerritt. Even the other voice actors are doing a great job. As a hole the sound design is great. The weapons sound like they came out from old western movie, which contribute to the atmosphere of the game. The music is phenomenal. When a track hits, you feel like you are in great adventure. And it is great.The studio hire hollywood screen writer and the outcome is pretty good story. You take the role of Colton White, who with his father, makes a living with hunting and selling the meat to a steamboat. The steamboat is attacked, because the bad guys are looking for something, that your father is hiding even from you. He dies, the boat is destroyed and from here starts your adventure. The story is great, but short, so don't rush with her. So is there anything else to do? You have a lot of side quests, most of them consists of killing everything that moves. But there are others, like get a cattle back to the their pens, making deliveries, protect people from wolves. And of course there are wanted posters. With them you often have a choice between dead or alive, which respectively brings you less or more money. When you are given a choice to get someone alive, the thing you have to do is to shoot the horse, cut him once or twice with the knife and apprehend him. You don't need to kill his buddies. And what is the wild west without a game of poker. In the two towns there are tables to play. The AI is not that good, but here is not that important.While walking around you can find gold, which you can dig. So the first thing you have to do when you see shopkeeper is to buy pickaxe. Other things you can buy from him are standard upgrades for your weapons, horse, but not for the bow. For him you have to visit an indian outside the towns. There are two shopkeepers in the game and they sell different upgrades.From everything I said until now, I almost didn't touch the gameplay. It's good. If you put aside the auto aim, everything else is great. You have pretty standard arsenal of weapons – pistols, rifles, shotguns, sharpshooter, whiskey bomb, dynamite and bow. My favorite is the shotgun. At close range is irreplaceable. After almost each story mission you will be given new weapon, each with different stats. In saddlebag you can choose which one to equip. The ammo for everything is not endless and you can't buy it. You have to find boxes with them in specific places spread around the world. Only for the pistols are endless and for the rifle are most easy to find.There is one more thing and it is Quickdraw. This is basically bullet time. With a press of a button, you slow down time and arrows appear to show you where the bad guys are. Then you pres left or right and start shooting without reloading. The feeling of killing 6-7 guys this way is awesome. When you slow down time, you can shoot arrows and dynamite, while there are in the air. Of course, you can move the crosshair with the mouse. In some cases it's very useful for more accurate shots. You can also go in first person view, for better shots with the rifle and bow. As far as the bosses, all I can say they are a lot of fun, especially the final one.Here is one interesting fact. Activision merged Neversoft with developer Infinity Ward in May 2014. In August 2014 it was discovered that inside the latest DLC for Infinity Ward's game Call of Duty: Ghost there was an easter egg of a fake poster advertising Gun 2.The game run absolutely fine on Windows 7, 64 bit. There is widescreen fix, but it stretching the HUD. When you type in 1 in HUD_PATCH inside gun_res.ini, it will fix the stretching, but the mini map will be almost in the middle of the screen.Gun is forgotten and underrated game. It's worth buying right now, if you don't mind the port. But it's definitely have to be played by everyone, who loves open world games and western movies. Gun is like human – it has some shortcomings, but if you look close enough, you will see beautiful soul underneath. From here you have to decide if you want to overlook the flaws, for everything else or not.

 Disclaimer - I do not own GUN, I have played the game via Steam family share and the hours recorded on Steam are not accurate either due to playing offline. GUN is an action adventure western themed game which was released ten years ago in 2005. This was my first experience with the game too, I had never played it on release. This is probably one of the first open world games to come out. The world consists of the story missions, side missions, gambling side activities and bounties to take care of.  As you travel on horse back from town to town, you encounter bandit attacks and ambushes which you can choose to either fight in, or escape with your tail between your legs. You play in a third person view of your character, Colton White. The game also has an auto-aim feature which I suppose was needed for the consoles back in the day, but on the PC it just felt clunky when aiming with a mouse. While you aren't out in the desert on story missions, another activity you can take part in is the hunting; you can hunt wild animals and then sell the fur and meat to be able to upgrade your equipment. There are plenty of classic western style weapons to be used in GUN too, from the revolver, to explosives and bow'n arrows.  This is also another game with a bullet-time feature in which can be activated once you fill up your Quickdraw meter and then switches into a first-person view. GUN also encourages melee action as well; with another wide range of different weapons to use here.The graphics do look dated; but for its time, this would of been top of the range. So if you are the sort that is discouraged by older looking games; GUN is certainly going to put you off in the graphics category. There are a couple of options which you can change to increase the graphical fidelity, but really any machine now days will be able to run this on max settings. GUN does have an element of difficulty to as well; I had to reply a number of missions from dying and messing up the objective. A full playthrough took me about eighteen hours to finish; this was with doing all of the side missions and activities as well. You are getting a really fleshed out game here. Since the game is old, I did have a couple of technical issues. The main one being the game will not support higher resolutions and will sometimes cause a black screen upon launching - I just had to minimize and reopen for it to sort out though. I did also have a few random crashes while playing too; so in order to minimize the risk of this, save often so you don't end up having to re-do levels you just completed and you'll be fine. I can recommend GUN; but only if you are playing it purely for the gameplay and story elements. Most will be put off by the aging looking graphics. however if you play it for what it is, a really well put together Western open world game. You will surely have a good time. 1) Stay away2) Only recommended when on sale3) Recommended4) Highly recommended5) This is a must playIf you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

												I thoroughly enjoyed GUN when it was released and I replayed it endlessly; it was so successful where Red Dead Revolver fell short - playing both of them back-to-back was very fulfilling.Despite this, for the so-so quality of the port (which I'm beginning to think is inevitable when porting old games,  Shame), $20 is STILL too high. If I was given the opportunity to buy a console version for $20, that would be a steal! Seeing as how, on PC, if you ride too fast through the relatively small world all hints of scenery, except for static objects, are prone to disappear, leaving you riding in the sky (but not for too long) – $10 would be more than fair, if you had an inkling of replaying this game. The more I've played it, though, the less often I've found such glitches.Remember, circa 2005, much less was expected from games. There is a respectable amount of diversions; I'm 6 hours deep and about 60% through - just sayin', don't expect an older ReDead Redemption. This is not that. If anything, it's ReDead Revolver with PERHAPS less refined combat but much more freedom and Native Americans instead of Mexicans, Animals instead of Carnies.Aye, when I recently replayed both Red Dead's, I kept finding myself thinking "When is [major incident from the story] going to happen?!" Every time I was anticipating such an event, it was always one that took place in GUN. So it seems, at least to me, GUN beat out ReDead in being epic... indeed, sometimes, while riding aimlessly around, the music can become TOO epic. As evident from the publishers, I really do stand by my saying that GUN is Tony Hawk with guns, regarding the sense of the controls/feel of it. Mind, I am playing with a controller - IT DOES HAVE CONTROLLER SUPPORT, YOU JUST HAVE TO MAP THE BUTTONS YOURSELF - when I first started the game, if you take a few steps and then stop abruptly, Cole continues sliding ever so slightly. LOL it's as if a remnant of the engine that defined the skateboarding. The longer you play, the less you'll notice it. Also: Never ride your horse with gun drawn unless you are in combat; having your weapon holstered, your horse can maneuver just as well as anything with wheels. I exaggerate only slightly when I say you can drift around corners on horseback.The gunplay is acceptable but nothing fantastic and you can't take too many bullets, even on Normal. For every few bullets, you'll have to take a shot - of Whiskey, oh yeah. Often, especially when horses are involved, it can be aggravating to try and line up your shots. Sometimes, it comes down to: drive your horse in circles, drive your horse in parallel lines, get off your horse. There is hardly ever that appropriate speed at which horse-to-horse combat can be fluidly achieved. The speed of things was something to be reckoned with in all games back then; remember how ANY time you had an escort mission or had to follow a story-dictating character while they walked and talked – if you moved at full speed, you’d leave them behind; if you walked, they’d leave you behind. So it comes down to Start.Stop.Start.Stop.Arggggh. …anyway, I don't know if I'm just lucky in doing this/lacking in skill for having to do this, but a tried and true method for me, that I've employed in several games when I can’t figure with the camera(/)speed: swing the camera haphazardly to aim, shoot, pray... watch it be a headshot... er, watch your enemy's head explode. Yes, there's chunky gore to be seen in GUN. Pistols, Shotguns, Rifles, Bows, Dynamite, Whiskey Bombs, Knives, Hatchets... 30(?) weapons in all. There are Stats that get upgraded when you complete missions, to help you in the progression of the story; it's a tale of revenge steeped in a revolutionary atmosphere - your actions throughout the Story make you more and more enemies, you'll be ambushed constantly by parties of 2 or 3 Bandits; sometimes the towns will be (")off-limits(") as the residents will seek your life. A typical half hour in-game could be something like:Shoot bandits off their horses (again, because of the iffy/sluggish camera controls (ON CONTROLLER), I usually will get off my horse and run around whenever enemies ride in on the beasts, it's much easier – just don’t get trampled) and then scope the scene for gold veins to mine, go back to your incapacitated enemies and scalp them, go to town and play Texas Hold 'Em, pick up a Pony Express mission that takes you to the Ranch in-between the two towns (Empire, New Mexico and Dodge City, Kansas), go check the store in the other town (while avoiding/destroying the Bandits/Indians/Haters-in-general), pick up a Deputy mission, dispatch with criminals, then go to the wilderness and find the Native American shopkeep and Hunter, all the while using your Quickdraw (GUN's Dead Eye) to kill birds and other wildlife. You cannot aim down sights with your pistols; not really sure why but that’s that. You can aim in the first-person with two-handed weapons, poppin’ dudes with your rifle, rippin’ ‘em in half with your shotty, or huntin’ the murderous Great Animals with your bow (really cool, really annoying). It has been stated elsewhere that, at least for controller, ADS is a toggle – if you continue holding the aim button and try to shoot, it’s a no-go. The Cast Includes:Whistler from Blade as your father, Ned. Hellboy as the criminal Mayor Brown.The Punisher as Cole, the hero. Keeping in mind that this is an old game, ergo perhaps lacking in content by today’s expectations: $5 = WIN. $10 = DEAL. $20 = LOL. Addendum: Playing on Normal, I've quickly found any sort of challenge to be nonexistent. I still stand by my recommendation, seeing as how, no doubt, only fans of Western Shooters or those of the game when it was originally released would seek this game out. For those who have not played it, it's (EITHER "is" or "was," sorry I can't commit to one or the other) a good game. You're a cowboy seeking revenge on whoever killed your father, who was involved with a madman looking for a fabled city of gold. I'll rate the game on a few criteria.Story/immersion: 9/10-The story  is great. Each character brings something new to the table. Each of them have their own unique personalities and are important to the plot in one way or another. The voice acting is also pretty good. Sure, it may be out of sync at times, but that never got in the way of me enjoying it. Also, it feels like I'm playing in a westerner, and although some of the scenes portray a few negative Native American stereotypes that seem to be a bit outdated, it feels genuine. I loved it, but honestly, the story should've been a bit longer. I beat it in 6 hours which, although average for the time, seems short for the kind of game it is. Controls: 6/10-This is one of the few places in which the game suffers. Moving is standard, as well as aiming, jumping, and crouching. What really could've had some work was the weapon system. You have plenty of weapons, don't get me wrong, but it's such a hassle to switch between them that I wound up using the rifle for most of the game. This could've easily been fixed if you could just cycle through with the mouse button. Instead, you have to use either the numbers or hold alt+the corresponding weapon key. Really bad in the heat of battle.Graphics: 8/10-By today's standards, an 8 seems a bit generous, but considering the fact that this game is from 2005, they really stand out. Even today, they don't look horendous. One thing I must say is that character models, such as NPCs and enemys don't render at full motion unless you are closer to them. Extra: 7/10-Throughout the game, there are plenty of side missions you can do to improve stats, gain money, and take a break from the main story. They're fun, and adds to the feel of the wild west. 												GUN is a very interesting game back from the old days. Well, to be honest, it's not that old of a game, but if you compare games made in this day and age to the tech of the old days, I'd say it's safe to call it old, but not ancient. If you've played Red Dead Redemption before, you'll see quite a few striking similarities between GUN and this game. I wouldn't be suprised if Rockstar got many of their ideas for Red Dead from this game, but there's absolutely nothing wrong with that, since inspiration is part of art anyway.I personally enjoyed the game and appreciated the open world it had to offer, although I did not enjoy the story. There are quite a few fans of the game that argue GUN is a much better game than Red Dead, but if you ask me, none of that is true in the slightest. Lemme elaborate my thoughts on this. You'll be able to understand this review a bit more if you've played Red Dead Redemption before, but if you're new to this genre, there's still a lot of information for you that's worth knowing.The Gameplay:Considering that the tech they had in 2005 was nowhere near as good as it was in 2010 when RDR was released, you can safely say that the open world in GUN is smaller and there is much less content. That doesn't mean the game is bad, and if you ask me, this game was pretty damn good for its time. As far as gameplay is concerned, you can ride a horse, explore the world, take part in side missions, or break the law, just like RDR. Also, remember the Dead Eye mechanic from Red Dead? You know, the one that allows you to slow down time and shoot enemies in slow motion? GUN had this very same mechanic five years before RDR took off where the game left and added improvements for it. As far as combat is concerned, you'll be put up against hordes of enemies attacking buildings and settlements, and you will take part in battles against your foes with allies. Shooting doesn't work nearly as well as it does in RDR, since aiming is dumbed down. Basically on GUN, if your crosshair turns red on an enemey, even if the crosshair's center isn't even on the target, you still still manage to shoot them regardless. With all that being said, the combat is repetitive but fun, filled with senseless violence and shooting you would expect from a game set in the Wild West. You can throw molotovs and dynamite, use pistols, use rifles, shotguns, you name it. A game like this was undoubtedly awesome for its time, but arguing that this game is better than RDR is completely laughable. The Story (don't worry, I won't reveal any major spoilers for GUN except the main character's name and personality, but there are major spoilers for Red Dead. I believe it's important to compare these two stories to get an idea of what GUN is all about):I remember hearing from somebody that GUN's story is better than Red Dead's. Before I played the game, I kept an open mind, and when I finally decided to buy it, I can definitely tell you that the story isn't executed well, even if you don't compare it to RDR. Am I saying the story is bad? First of all, the story's concept isn't bad, but the way it was executed was terrible later on in the game. Basically, the plot starts out this way: Something terrible happens to the main character. The main character sets of on a quest after a dramatic event, looking for answers about himself, and also trying to discover the sinister plans of his enemies. Is it different from RDR? Yes. For one thing, RDR's plot was rather simple, but there are complex meanings behind it. John Marstin (if that's how you spell the full name) was a criminal trying to fix his ways when the law holds his family hostage. He is essentially trying to pay the debt. Later on, John pays his debt to the law, which in turn stabs him in the back and kills him. His son grows up seeking personal revenge, and he finds the man who ordered his father to be killed, and kills him in return. What was Red Dead's story about? It was about the struggles of keeping morals when you live in a world where people only care for themselves. It was about dealing with the consequences of your actions, and how the desire to seek revenge for wrongdoings done unto you can turn you into the very people you despise. So yeah, RDR did have an amazing plot for sure, and the characters? Very well thought out. They fit the atmosphere of the game very well, which I will tell you more about after I talk about GUN's main character.So what makes Colton, the main character, different from John and his son? Well for one thing, even though this story is set in the Wild West, which means Colton is a gritty, tough hero like all heroes in a Western, one who is also motivated by personal revenge, you can easily argue that he still somehow manages to stick to the more noble path far better than John Marstin and his son.While many of GUN's characters, including Colt's allies, are believable, there is one villain I highly dislike. This one is a corrupt religious zealot working for the main villain. While I understand that he was a clergyman, the character design is awful. He looks more like somebody from the Middle Ages, and his personality doesn't fit well either. Other characters in the game, including the minions you shoot at, look more like a bunch of giants on steroids rather than humans. Now, for those of you wondering why I felt GUN's plot was poorly executed later on in the game, let me tell you why. It's rushed way too fast. On some missions, you will find yourself attacking an enemy base, and once you're done, you might expect a cutscene that will further explain the story and elaborate exactly what happened, but instead, you are immediately progress to the next stage. Is there anything wrong with more focus on gameplay? No. But there is something wrong with failing to elaborate on what you have done, and what awaits next BEFORE you progress. Conclusion:Yes, GUN is a good game, but considering that its open world has far less to offer, its gameplay has less features, and its story just feels rushed way too fast at the middle and the end, can you really safely argue that this game is better than RDR? There's no way you can. The point is that it is a gem worth playing, and it was definitely an amazing game for its time.

												I wasn't sure what to expect from this game. I vaguely remember hearing good things about it when it came out ten years ago. It definitely looks like an earlyish GameCube era game, and has a few awkward hiccups here and there, but overall it runs well, and I'm thoroughly enjoying it. My complaints so far are...-Key bindings could be more customizable. It won't recognize any buttons other than the L/R click on my mouse. I've accidentally button mashed myself to death on a few missions. The key to throw barrels of TNT is the same as the button to throw your selected grenade/explosive type weapon. One minute you're setting up an ambush in the intersection, the next thing you know, you took yourself out, and failed the mission for the tenth time. -Does occasionally crash. It's a well done port, but it's still a port, and isn't quite as stable as it could be. -THERE IS NO AUTOSAVE. If you fail a mission, it'll restart you where you picked it up, but if you quit the game, or it crashes on you, you'll pick back up exactly where you last manually saved. You have been warned.-Missions can be a little clunky. You have to blow up a boulder, but your tnt was dropped a few pixels too far away, and despawned, so you fail, and have to restart. You have to chase down a bandit that changes sprites in the gang every time you play it, and you'll fail even if you still have a direct visual on them, but they've moved just a few steps too far. You'll fail if you're doing an escort/follow mission, and stray too far ahead. -Crosshairs are more just boxes, and precision shots are tricky until you have a few hours in, and get a feel for how the hitboxes work. The Sharpshooter rifles are precise though, and since unlocking them, headshots are a breeze, even from horseback.Otherwise, it's a great game. The gameplay's enjoyable, the story's good, the map design is great, especially for as old as it is. I've lived in Colorado since '97, and the scenery really does capture some of the nostalgia I've gotten from travelling across the plains, and visiting old ghost towns and stuff.

content:
Posted: September 21, 2015
												GUN can be basically thought of as Call of Juarez, albeit more shooting and less running around dodging stuff. As Colton, you grew up under a harsh father learning to hunt and live off the land and horses and the rest. Until one day, your father told you he's not your real father, then to save you he threw you off the boat you've been defending as the boiler exploded. Your only clue is a token to the Alhambra Hotel, and Jenny, and a preacher Josiah Reed, who is working for someone... And it may involve Indian gold gathered up by Spaniards... The game involves shooting... LOTS of shooting. Pistol, rifle, shotgun, even a few whiskey bombs (i.e. molotov cocktails before Comrade Molotov changed it to gasoline) and later, precision rifle plus a bow. As you go through the plot missions, you'll unlock new weapons. And as you go through the game world, you can travel anywhere (between towns if you like) and indeed, some of the "gold deposits" you can mine requires buying a pick in town. A story mission would be escort the wagon through Apache territory (resulting in a couple checkpoints, including on horseback, static defense, go forward to find dynamite to clear a passage, then railshooter.  Another mission would be clearing the bridge of Apache presence, as they rush the bridge, check for explosives (you have to grab them and chuck them into the river) then escort the Chinese coolies to finish the job as Apaches attack, then finally defeat the Apache warrior leader with quickdraw and shoot fire arrows out of the air then kill the minions and finally leader himself. Betweens story missions you are encouraged to do the "side missions", which would give you bonus in various areas, such as pistol, rifle, shotgun, horse (speed), quickdraw, and so on if you complete them. The side missions are quite varied, including wanted posters (best if you wound the perp, then grab and knock out), but usually it's dead or alive (alive worth slightly more). Each town has a sheriff who will ask you to do things, basically run around town dealing with various troubles, usually involving shooting, but sometimes melee. There's also pony express where you need to make deliveries on a timer. There may be additional missions in town. Finally, there's usually a shopkeep where you can buy various upgrades, from fastloader for pistols to better knife to pistol upgrade (bore enlargement kit). There is a lot of terrain between towns, and lot of places to explore, and as mentioned before, there are gold in those hills (and you'll need a pickaxe from a shopkeep to get them). Finding them is part of the fun. As this game did come out more than 10 years ago, graphics are low-fi but good enough. Music is quite good, very orchetrally western. Voice acting is above average, though somewhat cliched. Gun sounds are adequate. The main problem is you basically spend your entire game depopulating the West, of one unsavory character after another. The game doesn't reallly have you do anything else (other then grabbing TNT barrels and chucking them, either into the river or put them at places where you do need to blow them up). The only time you really need to think was the wanted, where you TRY to sneak up on the guy but it probably doesn't work. While the controls can be mapped to gamepad, the game is best play with mouse and keyboard, where the added precision makes gun fights easier for you to pull off headshots or weapon shots (i.e. shoot weapon out of enemy hands). And in this game, you CAN blow enemy's head off. Rare, but it does happen, esp. with shotgun. Still, the game holds up even after 10 years, and IMHO, at some places, better than even Call of Juarez (the original) which has a very similar premise of sorts (in CoJ, people are also after the gold hidden and the protagonist is chased after by a nasty preacher with gun). If you can get it at bargain bin prices, it's worth a couple hours for sure. Just beware of certain nasty segments, like the quickdraw segments that require a lot of retries. And remember to save. A LOT.

												For the time being, consider this the closest thing you can get to RDR on PC. It's a fun game, but unlike Redemption I feel like a lot is missing. The map is small and the campaign seems kinda short. The world doesn't feel as alive and vibrant as it could be, and graphical bugs seem frequent (Weird walk cycles, people moving without a walking animation from a distance, etc.).But my complaints of GUN end there because the game is an excellent western title. You play as Colton White, a young man who has to carry out missions to find a crook reverend named Reed after he ambushes a steamboat you were on, taking your father and a ♥♥♥♥♥ he knew to the river deep. You play between Dodge City and Empire City in Kansas (Both well known as the pinnacle western cities in popular culture, along with Wichita and other towns) fighting off gang members, raiders, Apache Indians and so on.If you've played Red Dead Redemption before this game then you should feel right at home. It has a pretty straightforward third-person mechanic where you can get weapons like a Schofield revolver, a lever-action rifle, Winchester Shotgun, tomahawk, whiskey bombs (Essentially a Molotov cocktail) and much more. Gunplay is very simple and intuitive, normal for a TPS, and you can use your revolver to slow down time with a Dead Eye-esque mode called Quickdraw. Plus, you can ride a horse. Why would you pass that up?While not as developed and gritty as RDR's excellent western epic of a story, the story is still well-thought-out, although from what I've heard it's relatively short. You can also do side missions such as being a ranch hand, helping the local sheriff or marshals, and, a wild west staple, hunt bounties, among other things. The score fits so well with the game and story, that I could see it very well in a spaghetti western if the graphics weren't so...you know...2005.Overall, it's a great game and I'd recommend it if you're a fan of the wild west, Red Dead Redemption (Much like myself), or just games like these in general. It's a smaller-scale RDR and despite its dated and sometimes buggy graphics and small map, I suggest you give it a look.

												I have played this game extensively on Gamecube and Xbox 360. While the visuals may put you off at first, it will soon grasp you on the amazing story and stellar voice acting. The characters are very memorable, especially the  protagonist, Colton White, and his father, Ned, who he helps hunt fresh game in Montana for steamboats travelling the Missouri River. When travelling on the water after a successful hunt, the steamboat is ambushed, and Ned reveals to Colton with his dying moments that he is not his real father. Colton's journey across the West in the late 19th century is a tale of greed, brutality, and lust. It has one of the most gripping stories of any western game I have ever played. Sadly, as with being a western game, it is cursed to not sell very well. With the only exception to this rule beng Red Dead Redemption, not as many people have picked up this gem from 2005 - back when Activision was a semi-respectable publisher. It hasnt aged well, but the combat is still very fluent, if not a little repetitive. There are quite a few authentic sounding weapons from the time period, and you have an array of 6-shooters, hunting rifles, sniper rifles and shotguns to choose from, as well as melee weapons such as the bowie knife, cavalry sword, and tomahawk. Thrown weapons are added as well, including a whiskey fire bomb and dynamite sticks.The most unique mechanic this game has to offer is it's Quickdraw system. Yes,, it has been done in westerns before - time slows down, and you sling your pistol out and blast away at any man looking in your direction at the card table.Speaking of card tables, there a re quite a few mini games to be played here - poker tournaments, horse races, bandit raids, bounty hunting - you know, cowboy stuff. Overall, the game has a good story and atmosphere. You actually feel like you are Colton White, a man on a mission of vengeance and heroics - at the same time. Find Quivara, the City of Gold, and kill the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s behind the steamboat massacre all the while protecting the people from the dastardly Magruder, a failed politician and the trecherous murderer of Colton's true parents, which is an interesting character development as it is a complete surprise who his parents really were.  Tallied up, this game scores a 7/10, as long as you do not mind outdated textures and a rather small overworld map.

												Gun is the underrated masterpiece that too few had heard of. Gun is the game that Neversoft quietly made while most people were eagerly awaiting their next Tony Hawk game. Gun is the open world western of 2005, 5 years before Red Dead Redemption would hit stores as a critically and commercially successful western. People praised Rockstar for doing an open world western, but forgot about Gun.Gun is a gem, and everyone should play it. The story is strong. The voice acting from the leads, Thomas Jane, Ron Perlman, Kris Kristofferson, Dave Wittenberg, Lance Henriksen and Brad Dourif, nuanced and unequivocal. The soundtrack is perfect. The animation is outstanding. The gameplay is pretty good, but not perfect. There are so many reasons for owning this game and literally just one fallacy; the graphics.The only issue in Gun is the poor time release; late 2005, before the first next gen console would roll into stores, therefore, only taking advantage of what power the PS2 had left in it; and that's what PC gamers are getting, the PS2 port. It's not bad, hell, you can use a controller and configure it to your liking, all buttons mappable in the menu.Concering the plot, you are Colton White, voiced brilliantly by Thomas Jane. You start the game with your father, Ned White, hunting along the Missouri River. You fight some bears and this acts as the tutorial, learning how to shoot and whatnot. I REALLY don't wanna spoil anything, because the plot is so damn good. But from there, you end up on a steamboat to sell the meat with your father and a whole heap of♥♥♥♥♥♥♥happens. You meet one of the games antagonists and end up travelling to Dodge City. From there, you uncover mysteries of your father and your own personal past. The overall plot can be done in maybe 7 hours, but if you♥♥♥♥♥♥around doing side missions, bounty hunting, ranching, parcel delivery, being a marshal and deputy, you can squeeze in 12 hours or so.You meet these brilliant characters that come to life with, for 2005, really damn good animation; although the character's mesh will collide, the body motion is amazing and not robotic, like how some games are from over a decade ago. Whoever directed the cutscenes did their homework in film school, as the camera work is fantastic, tracking shots, over the shoulder dialog, full body view, some dutch angles. It's all intricate and brilliantly directed, I just can't believe this game was made by Neversoft, holy♥♥♥♥♥♥9.7/10P.S. If you're not already using ureschanger2 for older games that don't support widescreen, get ureschanger2 and follow the readme. It's very easy to use, just copy/paste the d3d9.dll and resolution.ini, changing the resolution to your liking. Once you get this bad boy in widescreen, the game looks a bit more glorious.

												I bought this game many years ago for PS2 and sunk hundreds of hours into and 100% completed it more than once. After what seems to be close to 7 years since i last played it i decided to buy it on steam today and relive it. I have a few grips about this PC port so far. Nothing terribly condemning but it is a significant annoyance. First off i want to say that its annoying this game dosent at the very least support 1920 x 1080p resolution. It max resolution supported is 1280 x 1024. Most games of this time made by big companies usually had native 1080p support on the PC. Why this game dosent i am not sure. Its not a big deal because 1280 x 1024 dosent look horrible. This PC port is graphically superior by a large margin compared to the PS2 version. The bigger issues i have noticed in this port is that it has a plethora of audio bugs. So far since i started playing it on PC 3 hours ago i have encountered 3 different audio issues. The first time was right near the begginning after the steam boat sequence loads. The winchester rifle was bugged with the same firing sound as Ned's single shot rifle. The issue went away after i died a couple times but it is still something to note. The second issue i experienced with the audio was a synchronization issue with one of the cut scenes. The Audio was about 3/4 to 1 second delayed with what was going on in the cut scene. The third issue was after the stage coach mission from Dodge to empire. Well near the river bank on the route that you take on this mission after you leave the canyon there appeared to be one of the ambient sounds from the mission still playing when you got within a certain vicinity of the area. That was the only bugs i have noticed so far. Gameplay wise i havent noticed anything yet. Still feels like the same good old game i played back on the PS2. Overall this game isent bad but it isent the greatest. The graphics where pretty shoddy even back in 2006 so it hasent aged well like games such as GTA 3. Regardless if its your first time playing it ever the gameplay may seem dull, and the world unintresting which for the most part it is. The world dosent have much in the way of detail and things to do but i wont hold it against it to much. The shining part of this game is its short but compelling storyline, playing through it is loads of fun and the gun play is quite entertaining. People that have played this before years ago the hit of Nostalgia is great but Nostolgic or not dont buy this game unless it goes on sale. It was on sale today for 50% at $9.99 and i bought it but i would still call that pretty steep. Ideally if it goes on sale for $5 then i say its a good buy. Its steam MSRP is $19.99 and it is by no means worth that much so if its priced at $20 dont buy it. That money could be spent on a better game.

												A friend of mine gave me a physical copy of GUN because he wasn't a PC gamer probably five years ago, and I remember slogging through what's probably one of the most generic,cliche-riddled action games I've ever encountered. I eventually sold the game (back before Steam when selling used games was still a thing; thanks Valve for taking away that revenue stream) but had an attack of nostalgia a few weeks ago and finally decided to pick it up on a Humble Sale for about $5.I never beat my physical copy of the game, though I was able to slog through to the end and its absurdly difficult boss fight. I never made it that far this time around, mainly because I decided my life was just worth more to me than playing through this truly awful game.Now, I'll get this out of the way first: certain parts of GUN are really good. For a game with such awful visuals the voice acting itself is actually quite good, with special mention going to Ron Perlman and Kris Kristofferson, and the soundtrack is also quite nice. That's really the most I can say about the game, though, as the rest is quite garbage.The story itself is just...I really don't know what to say about it, other than it feels like an absurd, over-the-top genre parody of actual Westerns rather than a serious attempt at making a good Western itself. Keep in mind, this was originally a Gamecube game so it's not really fair to compare it to later titles (most notably Red Dead Redemption) but the fact remains Westers as a genre had been around for a lot longer than video games, and there was so much other material the developers could've drawn in. Instead, we get a very strange arcade-shooter/RPG hybrid that never actually manages to make use of its own logical core mechanics. For example:There's an arbitrary stat buff given at the end of ever sidequest. There is not, however, an actual leveling system, so it's hard to really keep track of what these values actually represent.There are kill chain mechanics for killing large groups of enemies in a row with a specific combat style (i.e., chaining several kills with melee weapons), as well as for getting headshots or shooting weapons out of their owners' hands. Since there's no score or level up system, this mechanic feels completely pointless.There are several instances where the player is given a mounted weapon with infinite ammo and wave after wave of Valve-level stupid AI to slaughter. While this sort of works when that weapon is a Gatling Gun, it becomes ridiculous when it's a canon (and it's a canon most times).This, of course, isn't helped by the fact which the game is named after (the guns) are themselves pretty bland. Most of the weapons depicted are lever action, except none of them fire this way: the rifles fire on semi-auto, and the 1887 (the most iconic leveraction weapon in history) is a single shot shotgun. While it's nice to see a wide range of authentic Western shooting irons in the game, the fact the developers went to exactly no effort to make sure they were depicted realistically is disappointing.There are other mechanics which are handled much the same. Your character, Colton, and most of the people you run into are never especially interesting and it's difficult to take any of them seriously. This is compounded by some of the absurd things you and NPCs will both yell in combat (Colt, for instance, seems to think he's in Vietnam and will shout "Get some!" quite often for no real reason). The models themselves aren't animated well, and there's one constantly reused conversation animation that looks like it'd be right at home in the original Resident Evil. There are a lot of people who have lots of nostalgia regarding this game. I'm personally not one of them since I didn't enjoy the game when I first played it and I'm really not sure why I bothered buying it a second time. If you're someone who played the game back in 2005, you'll probably be content with the Steam version now. If you're not, however; if you're someone who's not ever touched it before, I highly recommend trying other more recent shooters instead (such as Call of Juarez or even Fallout: New Vegas) as both are much more rewarding. GUN had a lot of potential, but it never really goes anywhere and that's all there is to it.

												"You talkin' to me, punk?" 8/10I didn't play this game until 2014, almost an entire decade since it was initially released, but it's still one of my favorite gaming experiences in a long time, which was kind of surprising as when I first began my journey into 'GUN' I thought I'd play for maybe three or four hours tops. I mean, nothing about this game looks special at all. The graphics are dated, the voice acting isn't great, and it looks rather generic by today's standards in almost every way possible.It's safe to say that when I first picked this game up on sale, that I didn't expect more than 'Grand Theft Auto' on horseback. In fact, the biggest appeal of this game to me was the chance to do some good ole fashioned horseback riding; something I hadn't done since 'Ocarina of Time'. I never thought that I'd be so swept up into the dirty world of the wild wild west and the stories it had to tell me, but I was. From saving harlots, to chasing gangs down on horseback, to killing entire tribes of Indians in one fell swoop, this game includes every cliche you could possibly think about the wild west and I ain't complaining.Aside from the tight controls, camera angels, and helpless harlots though, this game is just down right fun. And even though it's hard not to compare it to 'Grand Theft Auto' I never found myself thinking I was playing some cheap clone just in a different setting. And did I mention there were harlots?

												Story TimeMany years ago when I first encountered the PS2 classic Red Dead Revolver I knew I was in love when I first played the game thanks to the western motive and styling as well as the enjoyable gameplay it brought as well. Now when was 4-5 years old I remember seeing commercials for Gun and always begged my dad to get it for me. Of course he never let and always gave me the speel of "Oh its violent" like any other kid my age at the time. Now 11 years later I now own the game and let me tell ya after those long awaited years my expectations have been none the more met.The Positives:For an old game running on a modern opperating system Gun runs flawlessly and despite how dated the game may appear it does pay a lot of attention to detail mainly in character models and atmoshpere. The controls are a little weird at first in my opinion and they could have been better but again this game is 11 years old so I will cut it some slack in that regard. You are also given plenty of variety in side activities that reward you with cash and stat points which give the game some light RPG elements and its almost recommended to do these side jobs when you can in order to progress at a smoother pace with enemies that pose a real threat. The Neutral:Despite the given variety in missions is does get a little repetative but not to much to where it will jade any sort of enjoyment for the player. The Negatives:Now if your all into graphics this game will dissapoint you since it is dated and it dosent support modern resolutions like 1920 by 1080 and the graphic options are also quite bleek with detail.Overall its a fun game with some smart writing and characters but overall just being enjoyable
